entry.title: My tiny side project has had more impact than my decade in the software industry
entry.summary: That‚Äôs a heartwrenching title from Michael Williamson. I believe it though. It‚Äôs kinda like a maximized version of the blogging phenomenon where if you work on a post for weeks it‚Äôll flop compared to a post that‚Äôs some dumb 20-minute ‚Ä¶ The post My tiny side project has had more impact than my decade in the software industry appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: The Fixed Background Attachment Hack
entry.summary: What options do you have if you want the body background in a fixed position where it stays put on scroll? background-attachment: fixed in CSS, at best, does not work well in mobile browsers, and at worst is not even ‚Ä¶ The post The Fixed Background Attachment Hack appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: Compound Components In React
entry.summary: Compound components help developers build more expressive and flexible APIs to share state and logic within components. This tutorial explains how this can be achieved with the help of using the Context API and React to build components by using this advanced pattern.

entry.title: Introduction to the Solid JavaScript Library
entry.summary: Solid is a reactive JavaScript library for creating user interfaces without a virtual DOM. It compiles templates down to real DOM nodes once and wraps updates in fine-grained reactions so that when state updates, only the related code runs. This ‚Ä¶ The post Introduction to the Solid JavaScript Library appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: How To Automate Documentation Workflow For Developers

entry.title: Creating a Headless WordPress Site With Frontity
entry.summary: Frontity is a WordPress-focused React-based server-side dynamic-rendering framework (phew!) that allows us to create fast headless websites. Chris has a good introduction to Frontity. I guess you could think of it like Next.js for WordPress. And while the demand ‚Ä¶ The post Creating a Headless WordPress Site With Frontity appeared first on CSS-Tricks. entry.title: Jamstack CMS: The Past, The Present and The Future
entry.summary: The story of Jamstack CMSs goes all the way back to the 90s. In this article, we take a trip down memory lane to see how we got to the modern Jamstack CMSs we have today, and where they‚Äôre heading in the next decade.

entry.title: Native Search vs. Jetpack Instant Search in Headless WordPress With Gatsby
entry.summary: Have you already tried using WordPress headlessly with Gatsby? If you haven‚Äôt, you might check this article around the new Gatsby source plugin for WordPress; gatsby-source-wordpress is the official source plugin introduced in March 2021 as a part of the ‚Ä¶ The post Native Search vs. Jetpack Instant Search in Headless WordPress With Gatsby appeared first on CSS-Tricks. entry.title: Creating An Interactive Gantt Chart Component With Vanilla JavaScript
entry.summary: In this article, we will code a Gantt chart as a reusable Web component. We will focus on the architecture of the component, rendering the calendar with CSS Grid and managing the state of the draggable tasks with JavaScript Proxy Objects.

entry.title: From a Single Repo, to Multi-Repos, to Monorepo, to Multi-Monorepo
entry.summary: I‚Äôve been working on the same project for several years. Its initial version was a huge monolithic app containing thousands of files. It was poorly architected and non-reusable, but was hosted in a single repo making it easy to work ‚Ä¶ The post From a Single Repo, to Multi-Repos, to Monorepo, to Multi-Monorepo appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: Free Open-Source Icons
entry.summary: Your project is on a tight budget? We‚Äôve collected some wonderful, free icons and goodies that we‚Äôve discovered lately and that are bound to give your design the finishing touch. We‚Äôve also just recently covered [Figma plugins](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2021/08/figma-tools-plugins-resources/), [SVG generators](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2021/03/svg-generators/), [accessible front-end components](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2021/03/complete-guide-accessible-front-end-components/) and [front-end boilerplates](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2021/06/useful-frontend-boilerplates-starter-kits/) ‚Äî you might find them useful, too.

entry.title: Tabs in HTML?
entry.summary: Brian Kardell shares a bit about the progress of bringing "Tabs" to HTML. We kinda think we know what they are, but you have to be really specific when dealing with specs and defining them. It's tricky. The post Tabs in HTML? appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: Using Web Components in WordPress is Easier Than You Think
entry.summary: Now that we‚Äôve seen that web components and interactive web components are both easier than you think, let‚Äôs take a look at adding them to a content management system, namely WordPress. There are three major ways we can add them. ‚Ä¶ The post Using Web Components in WordPress is Easier Than You Think appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.summary: Often you need two different sets of navigation stacks for pre and post user authentication. Usually, to see more content, you have to be authenticated in some way. Let‚Äôs look at how to mount and unmount navigation stack based on a met condition in React Native.

entry.title: Exploring the CSS Paint API: Image Fragmentation Effect
entry.summary: In my previous article, I created a fragmentation effect using CSS mask and custom properties. It was a neat effect but it has one drawback: it uses a lot of CSS code (generated using Sass). This time I am ‚Ä¶ The post Exploring the CSS Paint API: Image Fragmentation Effect appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: HTTP/3 From A To Z: Core Concepts (Part 1)
entry.summary: What exactly is HTTP/3? Why was it needed so soon after HTTP/2 (which was only finalized in 2015)? How can or should you use it? And especially, how does this improve web performance? Let‚Äôs find out.

entry.title: SVG Gobbler
entry.summary: Great little project from Ross Moody: SVG Gobbler is a browser extension that finds the vector content on the page you‚Äôre viewing and gives you the option to download, optimize, copy, view the code, or export it as an image. ‚Ä¶ The post SVG Gobbler appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: Efficient Infinite Utility Helpers Using Inline CSS Custom Properties and calc()
entry.summary: I recently wrote a very basic Sass loop that outputs several padding and margin utility classes. Nothing fancy, really, just a Sass map with 11 spacing values, looped over to create classes for both padding and margin on each side. ‚Ä¶ The post Efficient Infinite Utility Helpers Using Inline CSS Custom Properties and calc() appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: Three Buggy React Code Examples and How to Fix Them
entry.summary: There‚Äôs usually more than one way to code a thing in React. And while it‚Äôs possible to create the same thing different ways, there may be one or two approaches that technically work ‚Äúbetter‚Äù than others. entry.title: Frustrating Design Patterns: Disabled Buttons
entry.summary: How can we make disabled buttons more inclusive? When do they work well, and when do they fail on us? And finally, when do we actually need them, and how can we avoid them? Let‚Äôs find out.

entry.title: Using CSS Shapes for Interesting User Controls and Navigation
entry.summary: Straight across or down, that‚Äôs the proverbial order for user controls on a screen. Like a list of menu items. But what if we change that to a more fluid layout with bends, curves, and nooks? We can pull it ‚Ä¶ The post Using CSS Shapes for Interesting User Controls and Navigation appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: React Children And Iteration Methods
entry.summary: In this article, we‚Äôll discuss and learn about the use case of iterating over React `children` and the ways to do it. In particular, we will deep dive into one of the utility methods, `React.Children.toArray`, that React gives us, which helps to iterate over the children in a way which ensures performance and determinism.

entry.title: Serverless Functions as Proxies
entry.summary: The first time cloud functions / serverless functions clicked for me was when I saw and tried Auth0‚Äôs (now defunct) Webtask. It was a little CodePen-like IDE but you didn‚Äôt really see anything aside from code and logs. The ‚Ä¶ The post Serverless Functions as Proxies appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: Automatic Daily GitHub Backups, Restored in Seconds
entry.summary: Any company that uses GitHub for critical applications needs a backup that can be restored quickly when needed. Cyberattacks, human errors, or a forced push are just some of the scenarios that can result in the loss of GitHub data. ‚Ä¶ The post Automatic Daily GitHub Backups, Restored in Seconds appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: A Deep Dive on Skipping to Content
entry.summary: While most people browsing the web on a computer use a mouse, many rely on their keyboard instead. Theoretically, using a web page with the keyboard should not be a problem ‚Äî press the TAB key to move the keyboard ‚Ä¶ The post A Deep Dive on Skipping to Content appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: How To Build Resilient JavaScript UIs
entry.summary: Resilience is intrinsic to the web and therefore us, web developers. This article explores how graceful degradation, defensive coding, observability, and a healthy attitude towards failures better equips us before, during, and after an error occurs.

entry.title: CSS Modules (The Native Ones)
entry.summary: They are actually called ‚ÄúCSS Module Scripts‚Äù and are a native browser feature, as opposed to the popular open-source project that essentially does scoped styles by creating unique class name identifiers in both HTML and CSS. Native CSS Modules are ‚Ä¶ The post CSS Modules (The Native Ones) appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: How to Code a Playable Synth Keyboard
entry.summary: With a little knowledge of music theory, we can use regular HTML, CSS and JavaScript‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâwithout any libraries or audio samples‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâto create a simple digital instrument. Let‚Äôs put that into practice and explore one method for creating ‚Ä¶ The post How to Code a Playable Synth Keyboard appeared first on CSS-Tricks. You can support CSS-Tricks by being an MVP Supporter.

entry.title: Refactoring CSS: Strategy, Regression Testing And Maintenance (Part 2)
entry.summary: In this article, we‚Äôll take a deep dive into the refactoring process itself, and cover incremental refactoring strategy, visual regression testing, and maintaining the refactored codebase.
